posts.sub: How do I further develop my english skills
posts.com:
I'm an ESL and my first language is portuguese. I've never studied english formally through classes or textbooks, all I know I learned on the internet through immersion.
I can understand pretty much everything that comes my way unless it's some really obscure text with old english, and even then I can find my way around it.
The thing is, and I think this is normal, my confidence in outputting english in general is way lower than in reading and listening to it. I can make myself understood just fine, but I'm always questioning myself when it comes to grammar and whether a sentence sounds natural or not.
This wouldn't be an issue under normal circumstances, but the thing is I want to and have been working towards a career in translation.
I'm at a point where my japanese is getting close to my english level and JP-EN is a huge market so it would be the best one for me to aim towards, but I'm painfully aware that translating from a second language to another is a big disadvantage I'd have against people that are native english speakers.

TL;DR: How do I go about finding my flaws in english knowledge and addressing them so I can get as close to a native both gramatically and culturally? If that's even feasible.

>>27944149
>What would you do in my shoes?
First and foremost, get off the computer and out into public. The computer ain't gonna teach you social skills, people watching can at least give you a hint about interpersonal interactions and it will get your feet wet about the social anxiety. People feel uncomfortable if they receive unsolicited scrutiny, so make sure you invent a reason to be out watching people like you're enjoying the weather or waiting on someone.
Going to the gym will expose you to a sample of the public and help fix your obesity.
>Scared to drive long distances by myself
Why are you scared? Falling asleep at the wheel? Breaking down somewhere? If you feel this inability is truly crippling, take a scooter or bike with you on a bus when you go traveling or fork out the cash for a taxi. I've found that listening to music makes the ride much shorter than it seems. I moved >150 miles away from home, which sounds kinda daunting, but it's literally just three hourlong music mixes.
>Live with parents in a tiny town in the middle of nowhere
Move out, even if it's for a year or two in an apartment. The sooner you taste freedom, the sooner you taste loneliness, the sooner you begin to truly value social interactions. If you don't taste the artificial loneliness to steel yourself, you're going to have a rough time when you're parents pass away and you really are alone.

>Why do we hate the dating apps again?
The male-female ratio is tilted and gives women an even bigger edge, if they can put up with all the "Hey"s and unsolicited dick pics. I remember someone on here a while ago saying they were with one of the apps and that the algorithm is designed to give a new profile high exposure for a bit before it sinks into the masses. Every time you fork out cash, the algorithm puts the profile back towards the top. If you don't pay, the trick is to ignore the app for a while, and when it sees activity again, it tries to lure you back in by bumping the profile up again with higher odds that a sudden hit will make you want to split with more cash. Ever since I met the girl in >>27944121, I've been back to the app twice and both times, I magically got a like within a half hour, despite weeks-long dry spells while actively searching.
Unless you're hot or rich, your odds are roughly the same in all dating apps, with minor nuances in the types of people frequenting the apps.

>What's the main idea in this book?
Well I was kind of joking with "be like a nigger" but it's kind of true, but that applies more to direct game but to some extent to all cold approaching, niggers cat call and go up fearlessly and say you look so fucking hot etc. That's direct game. Day Bang is about indirect game though. The main idea in the book is that you talk about things that aren't personal to her because that scares them off, and it does. One of the things he talks about is "baiting". Baiting is that during the conversation about some item in the surroundings or whatever non-personal you drop little pieces of information about yourself which aren't too revealing, and where she would have to ask you a personal question to find out more. If she does that's a big indicator of interest, if she doesn't take the bait that's an indicator of disinterest. I had a date where I talked to a girl for over an hour and she didn't ask me anything personal the whole time, and most likely she was just in a social mood and wanted someone to talk to to kill time. An example of bait is something like "When I was in South America I ate this dish made of x and it was the spiciest thing I've ever eaten". If she just talks about something spicy she ate then she's not taking the bait. If she asks which country it was then she's taking the bait. He also says you might have to drop a few pieces of bait before she takes the bait.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have three recurring dreams.

In the first, some vast malevolent consuming force is trapped in a fragile prison, but in this cell a single flower grows. Consuming this flower will give the evil the strength it needs to escape and devour all, but the flower grows, heedless. The force absorbs it and shatters its bindings, consuming all.

I wake up. Wet with cold sweat, my breathing stills and my heart slows. I realise it was nothing but a dream and let it fade into the cold oblivion reserved for works of imagination.

In the second, I lie bound. Something chokes me. I scream and gnash. My teeth crumble to dust and gums mash bloody gums.

I wake up. Wet with cold sweat, my breathing stills and my heart slows. I realise it was nothing but a dream and let it fade into the cold oblivion reserved for works of imagination.

In the last, I lie softly in a world of tender light and warmth. I am embraced by her, as I always have been, and her hand tracks sweet curls in my hair, as it always has done. All is white and soft as snow.

I wake up. My breathing is calm and my heart is full. I realise it was but a dream, and panic sets in. The warmth, the light, all bleed away into the grey, and my desperate hands catch only mist. I writhe, and I don't get back what I have lost.

Dreams are not real, but they take elements from reality. Places, names, sounds.

She has your face. Your eyes, your voice, your smile.

My eyes see you and my heart sees her. It tells me, "go to her. You have known her your whole life. She is everything you have lost. Go to her."

You are not her. And I know that. So I go to you, to remind my heart that you are not her. But you are still you. Every kind word you say, every look that lingers too long, every little coincidence, it all sparks that little bit of hope that you are that perfect dream.

A childhood friend's mom died of cancer this weekend, and just now I found out. I remember the last time I spoke to her, about 2 years ago. She was coming from a doctor's office, and had a bunch of medicine in hand. She passed just as I was putting my little niece to sleep. I told this lady I was on track to becoming an engineer, going to school and working for a bit. It was a nice lie. I loved the ring it had, even though I dropped out long ago. She said her son was working at the local movie theater. I must have made him look bad in comparison, but I didnt realize at the moment. She must have felt slightly disappointed in her boy. If only she knew how bad things really were.

I used to look at my childhood neighborhood as a place full of good people. Some angrier than others of course, but most were mindful of eachother. As the years went on I tried to forget about the world, until I was able to overcome my depression and ineptitude, and "truly do my best!". Now that I can look away from myself, I see several houses run down, new strange, rude people have moved in, and there's even less unity from the neighbors as a result. The ones who still care are all 60+ now. My own parents are 60 now as well.

This will sound weird, but my dream is to make one of the greatest albums of all time. Honestly, I believe I have the potential to do it. But a few problems stand in the way:

1) I haven't made much music up to now. There's a few reasons for this - I'm a perfectionist so if a song isn't great I'm just never gonna do something with it. Plus for like ten years I had a misconception about songwriting - you can do it without fancy instruments or really anything. I spent all my teenage years not doing it because I assumed I didn't have the resources yet, when I totally did. So lately I've finally started making music, but...
2) I'm mentally ill. I can't enjoy stuff anymore, I don't feel emotions much, my energy is always low, my memory sucks, my circadian rhythm is really bad (insomnia), and so I can't really make music. But when I do feel emotions, I instantly want to turn those feelings into songs. I just feel stifled.
3) I'm 24. This is around the age most great artists start producing amazing stuff (my favorite artists made their masterpieces around 26-27, so I guess I have some time). Basically I'm afraid my natural creativity will peak in my 20s (it seems to for most people) and I won't be able to use it due to my mental problems. Still, I try to write songs most days but it just won't come. I need to be healthy again.

So that's where I'm at in life right now. Probably no one cares, but yeah

>what would you do?
That depends on the nature of her threat and her ability to carry it out. Is it blackmail? Spite? A desire to stay together with you? You need to know her motives to deal with her, whether you're doing damage control or trying to appease her.

I'm pretty risk-averse, so this is my take:
You should probably start looking for a way out of the company (and for a new job) while extracting as much as you can from it. First priority is finding a new job by leveraging your current role/connections, and doing so as soon as possible-- they won't be available if/when you're fired. While you're doing that, you should also be safeguarding any benefits that might be taken away from you if she makes good on her threat to get you fired, if there are any (for example, if the company provides matching contributions towards a retirement account, you could preemptively max that out). Make sure you do everything above-board, obviously, since the idea is to insulate yourself from the fallout, and if you use illegitimate methods, that will be used against you to take away even more than you would have lost to begin with.

Also, let this be a lesson about not flaunting taboo beliefs with physical evidence. Putting things in writing is bad enough, but having a bunch of outcast memorabilia is basically just a very risky LARP.

You're gonna lose. That's part of the learning process. Think of the greatest boxing or MMA champions they had to lose at one point, even fi they retired undefeated they faced countless losses and frustrations when training.

If you're serious about fighting then check out what combat sports are available in your area.
Watch out for mcdojos; check out their websites and online reviews, whatever combat sport category their martial art falls under they should have students competing in either amateur or pro fights and obviously do fairly well.
Also the teachers should be upfront with their lineage about where they trained and who they learned from, a lot of sports like judo and karate should be part of a national or international organization and their teaching lineage should be traceable as well. Even with modern MMA the sport is nearly four decades old so no one can still claim that they fought in 700 underground vale tudo bamboo pit death matches.

Also, no Krava Maga, Aikido, any Karate that's not Kyokushin, and anything that's Chinese except for Sanda/Sanshou.

And finally as far as street fighting goes, they'll tell you and I'll tell you that 99% of instances of people being rude to you or whatever is not worth the possible jail time and either your own or their own injuries or even death. There is of course that 1% where a crazy person is running straight at you or whatever but street fights are bullshit.

Meditation is a way that we can basically do good deeds.

So you know that when you do what you should do you do good things you feel good.

And what you feel when you do what you shouldn't do and what you feel when you do bad things you feel bad.

So meditation is just like the highest good deed it's a very strong powerful way to deepen the mind and the heart and be skillful because it's like we're training our mind.

So there are a lot of different ways to go about doing good deeds it's not just meditation.

It can be generosity, taking care of your body taking care of your mind, watching what kind of content you consume....

Especially generosity and doing good things for other people That's a big way to help yourself out and help your mind if you're just starting off.

Meditation can be quite difficult so you have to have a lot of intentionality you have to have a lot of sincerity to really get involved with meditation practice.

But for those people who aren't really ready to practice meditation you can still listen to talks from high level OGs in the meditation world and that's going to juice you up 100%

just like listening to LeBron James talk about basketball face-to-face hard to heart is going to juice you up when it comes to playing basketball.

There are LeBron James level Masters of the mind Masters of compassion Masters of transforming suffering so you want to connect with those kind of people.

Thich Nhat Hanh, Ajahn Brahm are a couple names you can look into


Also you can listen to guided meditations that can help a lot if they are coming from a good source.

So you've got to refresh and restart.

And how we set a higher standard for how we live and what we embody is really by being exposed to people who are on a deeper level have gotten even more involved than we have.

So if you are really serious about self-improvement especially in terms of the mind one of the things that you can do is attend meditation retreat, you can see if there's any Buddhist temples in your area that you could visit, and really the focus of that is to bring a quality of exploration to your life.

Going outside of your boundaries and being exposed to a new experiences that are going to set a new standard for what's possible.

The issue that we can easily fall into is that we get stuck in a certain way of living a certain way of seeing the world a certain kind of environment and then we just lock ourselves to think that that's the way that things are so you never really grow or mature.

It's actually that exploration that curiosity that questioning that brings us to investigate life more deeply but we have to do that as a practice it's not just about thinking or even consuming some kind of psychedelic.

You really got to be willing to follow and open yourself up to other perspectives other positions other people.

We all fall into those times right where we are in a very difficult and confusing situation and that's the opportunity to refresh and restart That's the opportunity to begin again to begin new 100% completely new experience completely new life and to do that all we need to do is come back to our breathing become aware of the present moment and take a step from a place of good intention.

Actually our story and our thoughts is not so important.

We should try to emphasize having a view that's based on present moment mindfulness and doing good deeds.

So if we find that we have a deep habit of being stuck on our complicated thinking and are self fixated view, then we should try to practice generosity and do more good deeds.

There is a particular view that we can have that is not about someone or something or sometime or someplace.

But rather to experience only here in the present moment and we can deepen and empower that view over time.

But the foundation of being able to do that is that we're involved in morality we're involved in doing good deeds were involved in living a meaningful life.

That helps to stabilize and simplify our mind and to help us be more practical and grounded.

You can totally transform the situation and free yourself but you have to start with doing good deeds meditation letting go.

Anway, seconding the education guy. Trade school is dead cheap and teaches jobs that won't go out of demand any time soon. The money you generate from a solid job will then be re-invested in other things.

If you want to invest in other things, decide how long you want your investment to run. Short term is riskier and needs more knowhow but has higher rewards. Long term has slower rewards but is safer.
>Short term ideas
Dollar stocks, Day trading, Small cap forex, shorting (very risky!)

>Longer term
Fractions of blue chip stocks (medicine or water are solid), Savings Bonds, Mutual Funds

>The crypto meme
I have been in this once since the Silk Road crash. We are past the point of early money and sitting somewhere between institutional money and the blowoff. Currently with the bear, unless you can find a good way to do shorts you are standing to lose money. People sell in spring and fall, buy in summer and winter- but that hasn't stopped the bear. Lots of heavy regulation coming in worldwide due to the implosion of TWO major exchanges. If you join in, look at utility vs price. What are the actual uses of the coin and is it worth the asking price? If the answer is no, don't buy. Ignore the shills and koolaid drinkers. Anyone who says "to the moon" or is betting it all on one coin has lost objectivity and will lose. That's true on any investment, really, but is especially bad in crypto.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27943660
>How dumb is it to leave my wife for this
Very.
It's not always a bad idea to end a marriage. It's an incredibly fucking stupid idea to do it impulsively without working on fixing the things that bother you first. If you had no children I'd say sure, go for it. But you do, and that leaves you with a mountain of responsibility and one of those responsibilities is to provide a stable, loving environment where they can grow up in and flourish. I don't care if you don't like it, come to terms with it. Seek out marriage counselling, talk with your wife, don't be resentful towards her and especially your child. Don't think of it as being doomed to stay with her forever, divorce is still an option, but you should explore every other avenue that is available to you first (short of cheating) and genuinely try to fix things before you go down that path. If nothing works and you do end up getting divorced, your number one priority over EVERYTHING ELSE is still the well-being of your child. I don't care if the process of divorce left you hating the mother, you'll not insult her, demean her or try to torpedo her life or relationship with her child - you support her to support your child. I don't care if you have a nice dinner date set up with your new partner, if your child is having a stage play at school, you go - whether it's playing the lead role or a tree in the background. If it's daddy weekend (assuming the child will stay with the mother) it means that all other obligations, short of emergencies and things that are necessary for survival, take a backseat.
Think about this long and hard, OP. Making it an impulse decision is the stupidest thing you could do.

don't move out while you're going to school. at least wait to graduate.

from my personal experience, make sure you have a job you like and make a good enough amount of money to pay for an apartment on your own. if you can't do that, DON'T MOVE OUT. Don't sublease. Don't pretend its okay if its with roommates and you pay a smaller portion. Don't feel guilty or shame for living at home with parents. You're super lucky they aren't charging rent. Mine do, $500 a month. Way better than anything else around my area.

Also make sure that you have goals. Focus on actual goals for yourself rather than 'what it feels you have to do'. Moving out isn't a goal, it's what you do when you need to reach a goal. You move to a new place if you get a new job, or find a gf. don't just move out cause it feels like you have to (if your parents suck then i would, but it sounds like they're nice if they're not charging rent)

spend this time developing yourself. Social, mental, physical, wealth, skills, hobbies, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27951203
It's not semantics though. Thinking in terms of *I* and *you* means identification of the self with the Ego / doer. When, in fact, the self is something else entirely...

The fallacy is believing in a subject-object relationship where the "I" (ego) is the subject and the "You" is the object. This however is a trick, because the ego in fact does not exist, it is a fictitious entity. It controls nothing, but insists on claiming credit for the things that happen.

The secret to happiness, or "enlightenment" as it is sometimes called, or even more accurately "the end of suffering" is to dissociate the self from the "I" and realize that it is neither the true self, nor in control, nor the subject of this narrative we call life.

If you are depressed, you don't realise your perception is being warped because depressed people always think they are extremely logical and objective. This is in fact an anti-cope, they have to believe this or the whole description of reality created by the depressed mind comes crashing down. So your first priority is ameliorating your depression. You can talk to a doctor, try some pills if you're up for it. Personally I found cognitive behavioural therapy the most useful approach in the long run. This can be with a therapist but there are also many books on this.
Secondly, sex has a special status in our culrure now, but on a biological level it's just a form of socialising, part of a spectrum of social activities of varying intimacy that humans naturally do. You can already socialise, we are socialising right now in a limited way. The more you socialise, the more you form relationships with people, the more likely it is that you will at some point have sex. I know you imagine that only the especially attractive or charismatic can have sex but this is objectively not true. Average guys have sex, fat guys have sex, even ugly guys have sex.

Work on your depression, work on socialising. Note that these are both long term projects.

i like looking at her because i think she's pretty but i don't want to creep her out.
i'm thinking about just going up to her and telling her that i just think she's really pretty and i'd like to get her snapchat/phone number, but i read on the internet that that's usually not a good idea. She might have lost some weight recently. should i comment on that/compliment her? help me guys.

tl;dr: how do i approach a woman who may find me physically attractive but is starting to realize that i'm cowardly/creepy/socially awkward before it's too late?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27951538
>i'm thinking about just going up to her and telling her that i just think she's really pretty and i'd like to get her snapchat/phone number, but i read on the internet that that's usually not a good idea
There are obviously unfortunate ways to go about it (i.e. going over to her in the middle of a set saying "hey I think you're pretty, can I have your number/snap?") but there's nothing wrong with asking her for her number. Just don't tell her you think she's pretty, that might be a weird thing to hear from someone you don't know yet and is implied if you're asking for her number anyway. Chat her up about her routine when she's resting post-workout and see if you hit it off. When it's time for you or her to go, tell her you liked chatting with her and ask her for her number so you can chat more outside the gym sometime.
>She might have lost some weight recently. should i comment on that/compliment her? help me guys.
Absolutely not. A lot of people are insecure about their body, especially gym-goers, and this could be seen as rude. You *can* compliment her (i.e. you're talking about your routines, she goes "I've been doing this exercise to get more toned", you could reply with something like "your efforts are definitely paying off, good job") but try to weave it into the conversation naturally.
>but is starting to realize that i'm cowardly/creepy/socially awkward
Stop giving yourself these labels. The way you treat yourself permeates all you do and will show in your interactions with others. Try to refrain them (i.e. "I struggle with social interactions but I'm trying")

>>27941983
Its already the TLDR, but if you insist. You must have experienced ambivalence regarding porn addiction. One the one hand you desperately want to quit, on the other you want to keep using.

The side that wants to quit is the real you. This is your neocortex, your thinking, deliberating, rational side. The "real" YOU. The other side is the Addictive Voice (AV), the "primal" midbrain.

The midbrain is a primal part of your brain that regulates breathing and basic survival instincts I think. Like to ensure that whatever you may be thinking, atleast you will be motivated to eat. And just like breathing and eating the midbrain has been conditioned to see pornography as just as important.

The midbrain has no real direct power over you. It cant order you to do anything. It is however a master in seduction so it will use your brains language, imagination centres etc to tempt you to use. Think flashing imagery, or it will try to get you into a negative argumental spiral. The AV comes from the midbrain.

We want to stop letting the midbrain run the show. So we identify its spokesperson, the AV. We learn how it operates, what it can do and how we should counter it.

By learning to fight against the AV we shut it up and thus solve ambivalence. With no ambivalence in place we suddenly find we can say no and just continue with our day.

In other words, we will start a boxing match every time the midbrain wants to, except we already knocked out our opponent when he leaves his house, let alone the ring.

Let me know if this makes sense.

posts.sub: How do I stop thinking negatively?
posts.com:
Whenever I should feel happy or at ease I worry about some hypothetical scenario that could make my life a living hell right then and there.
>What if I left the stove on?
>What if my thesis advisor thinks I'm and idiot and will slam the door in my face next time I drop by?

>>27948211
It probably starts with the understanding that most relationships between people are fundamentally transactional. People aren't necessarily looking to bill you for company but, generally speaking, most people that put time and effort in also expect to get something positive out. For most people, this can be as simple as a laugh, some good advice, or an entertaining conversation.

If nobody wants to spend time around you or talk to you, its probably because they're not getting anything out of your conversation, or you are an active draw on their emotional fortitude that outweighs whatever 'good' people can glean from your company. People who are whiny, overly negative, particularly judgemental, etc etc. tend to go far beyond what others want to hear.

Remember that most people out there already have to take care of one whole adult human being - themselves. The ones that have any room or wherewithal at all left after that get married, the ones that still have more time and effort to spare have children. They don't have the time or the desire to spend time helping you find yourself and most strangers are not going to care about building up your self-esteem. You're supposed to do that on your own and emerge into these conversations an already well-adjusted, adult human being that can take care of themselves. Everyone else is already too busy to do it for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Just read a bunch of different authors and see which ones you like.

Most writing can be broken down into actions, observations, and dialogue. Play with the balance between the three of them and see what feels good to you.

Remember you have more than 5 senses. You have a sense of time, space, balance, reality, etc.

Your first writing is going to suck but editing and polishing can be just as fun. Even pro writers need multiple passes.
